countercyclical buffer  30
6   losses incurred in  banking sector can be extremely large when a downturn is         preceded by a period of excess credit growth
these losses can destabilise          banking sector and spark a vicious circle
whereby problems in  financial         system can contribute to a downturn in  real economy  n feeds back on         to  banking sector
these interactions highlight  particular importance of          banking sector building up additional capital defences in periods where          risks of system-wide stress are growing markedly
7   the countercyclical buffer aims to ensure  banking sector capital         requirements take account of  macro-financial environment in which banks         operate

it will be deployed by national jurisdictions when excess aggregate         credit growth is judged to be associated with a build-up of system-wide risk to         ensure  banking system has a buffer of capital to protect it against future         potential losses
this focus on excess aggregate credit growth means          jurisdictions are likely to only need to deploy  buffer on an infrequent basis
the buffer for internationally-active banks will be a weighted average of          buffers deployed across all  jurisdictions to which it has credit exposures
this         means  y will likely find mselves subject to a small buffer on a more         frequent basis
since credit cycles are not always highly correlated across         jurisdictions
8   the countercyclical buffer regime consists of  following elements

national authorities will monitor credit growth and or indicators  may             signal a build up of system-wide risk and make assessments of wher             credit growth is excessive and is leading to  build up of system-wide risk
based on this assessment y will put in place a countercyclical buffer             requirement when circumstances warrant
this requirement will be released             when system-wide risk crystallises or dissipates

internationally active banks will look at  geographic location of ir             private sector credit exposures and calculate ir bank specific             countercyclical capital buffer requirement as a weighted average of              requirements  are being applied in jurisdictions to which y have credit             exposures
the countercyclical buffer requirement to which a bank is subject will extend              size of  capital conservation buffer
banks will be subject to             restrictions on distributions if y do not meet  requirement

definition of market risk  10
1   market risk is defined as  risk of losses in on and off-balance-sheet positions         arising from movements in market prices
the risks subject to this requirement         are
the risks pertaining to interest rate related instruments and equities in              trading book
foreign exchange risk and commodities risk throughout  bank
scope and coverage of  capital requirements  10
2   the capital requirements for interest rate related instruments and equities will         apply to  current trading book items prudently valued by banks
alongside         cap50
the definition of trading book is set out in rbc25
3   all transactions
including forward sales and purchases
shall be included in          calculation of capital requirements as from  date on which y were entered         into
although regular reporting will in principle take place only at intervals
in         most countries quarterly
banks are expected to manage  market risk in ir         trading book in such a way   capital requirements are being met on a         continuous basis
ie at  close of each business day

supervisory authorities         have at ir disposal a number of effective measures to ensure  banks do not         window-dress by showing significantly lower market risk positions on reporting         dates
banks will also
of course
be expected to maintain strict risk management         systems to ensure  intra-day exposures are not excessive
if a bank fails to         meet  capital requirements
national authority shall ensure   bank         takes immediate measures to rectify  situation
4   the capital requirements for foreign exchange risk and for commodities risk will         apply to banks total currency and commodity positions
subject to some         discretion to exclude structural foreign exchange positions
it is understood          some of se positions will be reported and hence evaluated at market value
but some may be reported and evaluated at book value
5   a matched currency position will protect a bank against loss from movements in         exchange rates
but will not necessarily protect its capital adequacy ratio
if a         bank has its capital denominated in its domestic currency and has a portfolio of         foreign currency assets and liabilities  is completely matched
its capital/asset         ratio will fall if  domestic currency depreciates
by running a short position in          domestic currency  bank can protect its capital adequacy ratio
although          position would lead to a loss if  domestic currency were to appreciate
6   supervisory authorities are free to allow banks to protect ir capital adequacy         ratio in this way
thus

any positions which a bank has deliberately taken in order         to hedge partially or totally against  adverse effect of  exchange rate on its         capital ratio may be excluded from  calculation of net open currency positions

such positions need to be of a structural
ie of a non-dealing
nature

positions in or banks

and or financial         entities eligible regulatory capital instruments

pillar 3 of  basel framework aims to promote         market discipline through regulatory disclosure requirements

these         requirements enable market participants to access key information relating to a         banks regulatory capital and risk exposures in order to increase transparency and         confidence about a banks exposure to risk and  overall adequacy of its         regulatory capital

last review of  core principles  01
1   the core principles for effective banking supervision
core principles
are  de         facto minimum standard for sound prudential regulation and supervision of         banks and banking systems
originally issued by  basel committee on banking         supervision
committee
y are used by countries as a benchmark         for assessing  quality of ir supervisory systems and for identifying future         work to achieve a baseline level of sound supervisory practices
the core         principles are also used by  international monetary fund
imf
and  world         bank
in  context of  financial sector assessment programme
fsap
to         assess  effectiveness of countries banking supervisory systems and practices
2   in march 2011
core principles group1 was mandated by  committee to         review and update  core principles
the committees mandate was to conduct          review taking into account significant developments in  global financial         markets and regulatory landscape since october 2006
when  core principles         had last been revised
including post-crisis lessons for promoting sound         supervisory systems
the intent was to ensure  continued relevance of          core principles for promoting effective banking supervision in all countries over         time and changing environments
the core principles group consisted of members from  committee                     and  basel consultative group
which comprises representatives                     from both committee and non-committee member countries and                     regional groups of banking supervisors
as well as  imf
world                     bank and  islamic financial services board
see
for example
november 2010 financial stability board report                     on intensity and effectiveness of systemically important financial                     institution supervision
january 2010 joint forum report on review                     of  differentiated nature and scope of financial regulation  key                     issues and recommendations
and  october 2009 senior supervisors                     group report on risk management lessons from  global banking                     crisis of 2008
3   in conducting  2011 review
committee sought to achieve  right         balance in raising  bar for sound supervision while retaining  core         principles as a flexible
globally applicable standard
by reinforcing          proportionality concept
revised core principles and ir assessment criteria         accommodate a diverse range of banking systems

the proportionate approach         also allows assessments of compliance with  core principles  are         commensurate with  risk profile and systemic importance of a broad spectrum         of banks
from large internationally active banks to small
non-complex deposit
taking institutions
4   both  core principles and  associated core principles methodology
assessment methodology
have served ir purpose well in terms of helping         countries to assess ir supervisory systems and identify areas for improvement
while conscious efforts were made during  2011 review to maintain continuity         and comparability as far as possible
committee merged  core principles         and  assessment methodology into a single comprehensive document
the         revised set of twenty-nine core principles were also reorganised to foster ir         implementation through a more logical structure starting with supervisory         powers
responsibilities and functions
and followed by supervisory expectations         of banks
emphasising  importance of good corporate governance and risk         management
as well as compliance with supervisory standards

the core principles methodology was separately developed in 1999                     and subsequently revised in 2006 to provide furr details and                     guidance on  assessment criteria and  assessment of compliance                     with  core principles
5   important enhancements were introduced into  individual core principles         during  review
particularly in those areas  are necessary to strengn         supervisory practices and risk management
various additional criteria were         upgraded to essential criteria as a result
while new assessment criteria were         warranted in or instances
close attention was given to addressing many of          significant risk management weaknesses and or vulnerabilities highlighted         in  last crisis
in addition
review took account of several key trends and         developments  emerged during  last few years of market turmoil
need         for greater intensity and resources to deal effectively with systemically important         banks
importance of applying a system-wide
macro perspective to          microprudential supervision of banks to assist in identifying
analysing and taking         pre-emptive action to address systemic risk
and  increasing focus on effective         crisis management
recovery and resolution measures in reducing both          probability and impact of a bank failure
the committee sought to give         appropriate emphasis to se emerging issues by embedding m into          core principles
as appropriate
and including specific references under each         relevant principle
6   in addition
sound corporate governance underpins effective risk management         and public confidence in individual banks and  banking system
given         fundamental deficiencies in banks corporate governance  were exposed in          last crisis

a new core principle on corporate governance was added in this         review by bringing toger existing corporate governance criteria in          assessment methodology and giving greater emphasis to sound corporate         governance practices
similarly

committee reiterated  key role of robust         market discipline in fostering a safe and sound banking system by expanding an         existing core principle into two new ones dedicated respectively to greater public         disclosure and transparency
and enhanced financial reporting and external audit
7   previously
grading of compliance with  core principles was based solely         on  essential criteria
to provide incentives to jurisdictions
particularly those          are important financial centres
to lead  way in  adoption of          highest supervisory standards
revised core principles allow countries          additional option of voluntarily choosing to be assessed and graded against          essential and additional criteria
in  same spirit of promoting full and robust         implementation
committee retained  existing four-grade scale of         assessing compliance with  core principles

this includes  current         materially non-compliant grading  helps provide a strong signalling effect         to relevant authorities on remedial measures needed for addressing supervisory         and regulatory shortcomings in ir countries
